articles.title: The WHO held off on declaring the Wuhan coronavirus a global health emergency. Here’s why.
articles.description: These decisions are an uneasy balancing act between science and politics.
articles.content:
Chinas coronavirus outbreak has prompted some travel restrictions. That could backfire.
This isnt the first time the WHO has been reluctant to declare a PHEIC

articles.author: Simon Denyer, Lyric Li
articles.title: China bans wild animal trade until coronavirus epidemic eliminated
articles.description: Scientists have linked the coronavirus and SARS epidemics to markets where wild animals were sold to be eaten.
articles.content:
The new restrictions ban the transport and sale of wild animals, specifically banning markets, supermarkets, restaurants and e-commerce platforms from trading in any form.

articles.content:
More than 50 million people were ordered on lockdown in central China with a travel ban covering 16 cities in the central Hubei province, where the virus was first encountered. Heres what we know:

articles.title: US Consulate to evacuate staff from epidemic-stricken Wuhan
articles.description: The U.S. Consulate in the epidemic-stricken Chinese city of Wuhan will evacuate its personnel and some private citizens aboard a charter flight Tuesday
articles.content:
It said that in the event there are not enough seats, priority will be given to to individuals at greater risk from coronavirus, a new respiratory disease that has sickened 1,975 people and killed 56, almost all in Wuhan.
